description: Rang in the new year with loved ones. May 2020 bring you an abundance of happiness and joy as we continue to fight for a better future for all.
I've always only had one client: the people.

When I was a young girl visiting my grandparents in India, I‚Äôd join my grandfather and his buddies on their morning walk along the beach as they would talk about the importance of fighting for democracy and civil rights. Those walks made me who I am today and it‚Äôs why I‚Äôm proud to launch our South Asians For The People community. Join us by clicking the link in my bio.
Picking out apples in New Hampshire at Mack‚Äôs Apple Stand. The Mack Family has farmed the land since 1732, making it the oldest single family-run farm in the Granite State.
While everybody is distracted by Trump‚Äôs crazy tweets, he‚Äôs quietly undoing environmental regulations that were built over years to protect our environment.
This is a fight against powerful interests. Leaders need to lead. So my message to Republicans on this issue is this: Lead, follow, or get out the way.

Every day, Jenn plays a role in making sure we‚Äôre giving all Americans the opportunity to build a better life for their family. To her and to myself, this fight is personal. Together we're proud to announce the launch of APIAs for the People. (Link in bio to join us)

My climate plan would take on powerful interests to build a clean economy that creates millions of jobs and guarantee every person‚Äôs right to breathe clean air and drink clean water. (Link in bio to read my Climate Plan For the People.)

I‚Äôm so inspired by the young leaders I meet across the country who are showing up and getting involved in our democracy. They deserve a president who will fight for them and their future ‚Äî I‚Äôm ready to be that leader.

This Labor Day, I joined union members at a rally in Los Angeles to fight for fair labor practices, better wages, and quality health care. Together we can ensure working people have the dignity that they deserve. More in stories.

Thurgood Marshall, one of the heroes and inspirations of my youth, was confirmed by the Senate to the Supreme Court on this day in 1967. Our nation is made better because of his work and presence. His legacy calls us to continue to be a voice for justice and truth.

Our campaign is powered by teachers, nurses, firefighters, and hardworking Americans who believe in our values and have chipped in $5 when they can. Click the link in bio to join them in fighting #ForThePeople.

Where every single person can retire with dignity. Where we can all breathe clean air and drink clean water. Where Black women aren‚Äôt three to four times more likely to die in childbirth than white women.

A country where we stop incentivizing corporations to profit off the incarceration of millions. We‚Äôre going to fight for an America where all our civil rights are respected.

I wouldn‚Äôt be part of Kavanaugh‚Äôs confirmation hearings had Chief Justice Warren not been on the Supreme Court to lead the unanimous decision in Brown v. Board. Had someone else been there, I may not have become a U.S. Senator.

I know the impact one Justice can have.

Two years after California legalized same-sex marriage, Obergefell v. Hodges declared that everyone across the country has the right to marry the person they love. It was one of the great moments in the history of the Supreme Court. Despite repeated questioning, Kavanaugh refused to say it was correctly decided.

Make no mistake, the most critical legal cases could be decided by Judge Kavanaugh, including:
‚ÜíAccess to health care and contraception
‚ÜíMoney in politics

‚ÜíVoting rights
‚Üí Executive power

Constance Baker Motley was confirmed as the first Black woman to become a District Court Judge on this day in 1966. She was a legal advocate in the Civil Rights Movement and inspired me from a young age to fight for the voiceless and for justice.

When talking about the March on Washington, besides Dr. King, there are two other people you should know about: Mahalia Jackson and Bayard Rustin. 
During Dr. King‚Äôs speech, singer Mahalia Jackson shouted, ‚ÄúTell them about the dream, Martin!" which led to King improvising his remarks to proclaim his dream of a nation where children are judged not by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. 
Bayard Rustin, an openly gay man, was the chief organizer of the March on Washington. Dr. King‚Äôs had full confidence in Rustin -- and it led him to organize one of the most well-attended marches in our nation‚Äôs history.

Gilbert Baker, the designer of the rainbow flag, created a symbol of pride for the LGBTQ movement. He created the rainbow flag in 1978 and refused to trademark it because he wanted it to belong to the entire LGBTQ community. The original flag had eight colors, each representing a different aspect of humanity: pink for sexuality, red for life, orange for healing, yellow for the sun, green for nature, turquoise for magic, blue for serenity, and purple for the spirit. Until his death last year, Gilbert never stopped creating flags and advocating for the LGBTQ community. #Pride

I am deeply disappointed Congress has given the OK to loosen the rules on some Wall Street banks. Removing common-sense safeguards that protect consumers is beyond irresponsible ‚Äî we are repeating the same mistakes that created the 2008 financial crisis.

The reforms under Dodd-Frank were created to ensure greater accountability and enforcement of the big banks. Hard-working American families deserve to have the peace of mind that they aren't going to be duped by a system designed for big banks to profit at their expense.

When I was Attorney General, I saw firsthand the devastation of the financial crisis, with more than 150,000 California families losing their homes to foreclosure. My team fought to make things right for them, and in 2012 we delivered a $20 billion settlement from the big banks to California homeowners.

I am committed to bringing accountability, responsibility, and honesty to Wall Street, and I hope you'll stand with me in this fight.

Like many of you, I‚Äôm spending today thinking about my mother. She was all of 5 feet, but she could move mountains, as she proved when she crossed an ocean at age 19 to study in America.

There‚Äôs a photo I cherish of her and one of her best friends in life, my Auntie Lenore, standing in front of a sign that says, ‚ÄúProtest Birmingham atrocities. Write the president.‚Äù She and my father met while they were active in the civil rights movement. My sister Maya and I actually joke that we grew up surrounded by a bunch of adults marching and shouting for this thing called justice. We were raised on the stories of the upheaval and activism of the 1960s.

My mother became a pioneering breast cancer researcher. She maintained her lab at Lawrence Berkeley until the day she died; she knew that the search for truth was a lifelong effort. 
From her, I learned to ask questions, gather evidence, and test hypotheses. I learned no idea is too precious to be rigorously examined. I learned how to fight for justice and live a life of conscience, and I think of her every day.
I say to all women and girls: own your voice and own your power. Carry it. Be proud of it. Always know that, whatever you're thinking or you're feeling, your voice is important and should be heard.

Sylvia Mendez, a civil rights activist, was born in Orange County, California. Back in 1943, students of Mexican descent were required to attend separate schools from Caucasian children. After her family discovered the all-white school provided a better education, they tried to enroll Sylvia in that school but was initially denied admission. Her father took the case to court and a victorious outcome made Sylvia the first student of Mexican descent to attend a segregated all-white school in California, paving the way for California to become the first state in the nation to end segregation in schools. #WomensHistoryMonth

In 1955, Claudette Colvin was arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat to a white passenger. Claudette became one of the plaintiffs in Browder v. If she had not done what she did, I am not sure that we would have been able to mount the support for Mrs. Parks.‚Äù

Gun violence has become routine in America. We have lost too many of our classmates, friends, family members, and children to this epidemic of mass shootings. As a nation, we are weary -- but the leadership and courage of the students, faculty, and parents at Stoneman Douglas High School is creating new energy in this fight. Now is the time for Congress to follow their lead. Let‚Äôs honestly acknowledge the epidemic of gun violence -- and the corrupting influence of the gun lobby in Washington. Let‚Äôs bust the false choice that you can either support the Second Amendment or support reasonable gun safety laws. Let‚Äôs work now to ban weapons of war whose primary purpose is to kill the largest number of human beings in the shortest amount of time possible. Let‚Äôs get this done and keep our schools safe.

Track and field star Alice Coachman made history at the 1948 Olympic games by becoming the first Black woman to win a gold medal. Growing up in Albany, Georgia, Coachman was often unable to use the segregated training facilities. She persevered, training barefoot and with old equipment before receiving a scholarship to Tuskegee Institute. In 1948, she competed in the Olympics. Hers was the only gold medal won by an American woman in track and field that year at the Olympics, and it earned her a Coca-Cola endorsement deal ‚Äî the first Black person to do so. #BlackHistoryMonth

Californian Betty Reid Soskin, the oldest @nationalparkservice ranger in the United States, spoke with @luvvie at the @makerswomen conference about how we all have a responsibility to participate in forming a more perfect union. #BlackHistoryMonth

Mari Copeny, also known as ‚ÄúLittle Miss Flint,‚Äù is an activist raising awareness about the water crisis that has been plaguing Flint, Michigan since 2014. At age 8, Mari became well-known when she wrote a letter to President Obama asking him to meet with her regarding the Flint water crisis. In her quest to make sure people don‚Äôt forget about Flint, she has organized water bottle drives for her community and raised money to provide over a thousand Flint students with backpacks and school supplies. Mari has proven that it doesn‚Äôt matter your age, you can always make a difference in your community. #BlackHistoryMonth

Known for his insightful writings on racial and social issues, James Baldwin‚Äôs talent and passion for articulating American life made him an important voice in the United States and abroad. Born into poverty in Harlem in 1924, Baldwin‚Äôs writing career started in Greenwich Village where he wrote freelance book reviews, until moving to France in 1948. His first novel, the semi-autobiographical ‚ÄúGo Tell it on the Mountain,‚Äù told of the Black struggle in impoverished Harlem. Throughout his life, Baldwin wrote several more novels, plays, and essays focusing on issues such as race, spirituality, and sexuality. #BlackHistoryMonth

Hattie McDaniel, the first Black entertainer to win an Academy Award, was born in Kansas to a Civil War veteran and a singer. McDaniel‚Äôs natural performing skills led to her pursuing an acting career. In 1934, she landed a role in The Little Colonel, with Shirley Temple. Because acting jobs for Black actors were competitive and hard to come by, McDaniel took odd jobs between gigs. Hattie McDaniel earned the part of Mammy, the housemaid in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind. She would later receive the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress for her role. After her death, McDaniel was posthumously awarded two stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. #BlackHistoryMonth
There's not a left and right when it comes to DACA. Frankly, I think there's a wrong and a right. Period.

Inspired by tales of World War I pilots, Bessie Coleman was determined to fly ‚Äî and she did, becoming the first Black woman to earn a pilot‚Äôs license. Rejected from American aviation schools due to her race and gender, Coleman taught herself French and headed to Europe, where she received her international pilot‚Äôs license in 1921. ‚ÄúQueen Bess‚Äù returned to America and performed acrobatic stunts in air shows around the country until her death in 1926.

Thurgood Marshall was the first Black man appointed to the United States Supreme Court. Born in Maryland, Marshall grew up interested in law and went on to attend law school at Howard University. In 1954, he argued and won the Brown v. Board of Education case which helped end racial segregation in public schools. Throughout this life, Marshall served as a liberal voice on civil rights and social justice. #BlackHistoryMonth

Madam C.J. Walker didn‚Äôt become the first American woman self-made millionaire by selling hair products alone ‚Äî she sold a lifestyle. After suffering from hair loss due to a scalp condition, she sought out remedies to improve her own hair. Upon realizing many Black women were also experiencing the same hair problems, Walker created a line of hair care products in 1905. She traveled the country giving lectures on her ‚ÄúWalker Method‚Äù of hair care to other Black women, and just three years later, Walker opened her own factory and beauty school where she eventually employed several thousand women. #BlackHistoryMonth

In 1992, thirty-one years after America first launched a man into space, Dr. Mae Jemison became the first black woman in space. ‚ÄúOnce I got into space, I was feeling very comfortable in the universe. I felt like I had a right to be anywhere in this universe, that I belonged here as much as any speck of stardust, any comet, any planet,‚Äù she said. While on board the Endeavour for eight days, Jemison conducted experiments on weightlessness and motion sickness, on both the crew and herself.

My advice to Black girls everywhere: Whenever someone tells you your dreams aren't achievable, whenever you feel alone or under pressure, whenever you find yourself in a room where there aren't a lot of people who look like you ‚Äî be it a classroom, or a boardroom, or a courtroom ‚Äî remember that you have an entire community in that room with you, all of us encouraging you and cheering you on.

Today marks the first day of Black History Month. Throughout the month, I‚Äôm going to highlight the lives and accomplishments of individuals in the black community who have helped shape our nation.

I wanted to begin with Michelle Howard, who was the first woman to become a four-star admiral in the U.S. Navy. Born in California, Howard was raised by a military family and by the time she was 12, she had started thinking about a career in the military. In 1982, she graduated from the United States Naval Academy and in 1999, she became the first black woman to command a U.S. naval warship when she took command of the USS Rushmore. Fifteen years later, Howard made history when she became the first woman promoted to the rank of a four-star admiral. #BlackHistoryMonth

Exactly one year after President Trump was sworn into office, our government has shut down. Americans don‚Äôt deserve this dysfunction ‚Äî they want the government to work and to pass legislation that protects the people. What‚Äôs standing in the way of this is the chaotic White House and the partisanship of Republican leaders. I say to them, let‚Äôs find some common ground so we can reopen the government and ensure federal workers are paid. I‚Äôm optimistic that we can work together this weekend on a long-term funding bill that supports our military, community health centers, CHIP, disaster relief, and protects Dreamers from deportation.

History is going to show that Republican leaders in Washington are on the wrong side of this fight when they stand in the way of fairness and justice for Dreamers, for kids who need health care, and for federal employees facing furloughs when they live paycheck to paycheck. Enough with the games.

Republicans control the White House, the House, AND the Senate. Roberto Clemente, born in Puerto Rico, was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame. As a child, Roberto grew up playing sports and at 17 he played for the Santurce Crabbers of the Puerto Rican Baseball League. A year later, he signed a minor league deal with the Dodgers before moving to the Pittsburgh Pirates. Roberto would go on to win four National League batting titles, the NL Most Valuable Player Award and twelve straight Gold Glove Awards. In the 1972 season, he reached 3,000 career hits before he was killed in a plane crash while transporting supplies to survivors of a Nicaragua earthquake. #HispanicHeritageMonth

In 2009, Justice Sonia Sotomayor became the first Latina United State‚Äôs Supreme Court Justice. Justice Sotomayor grew up in New York City and became interested in law after she started watching legal dramas on TV. During Hispanic Heritage Month, we honor C√©sar E. Ch√°vez, the great labor leader and civil rights activist. Early in his life, Ch√°vez worked in California‚Äôs fields doing backbreaking labor, which propelled him to fight for improved farmworker conditions. In 1962 he founded what would later become the United Farm Workers, bringing attention to the plight of farmworkers through nonviolent means. ‚ÄúWhen my husband lost his job, the Affordable Care Act helped us as we got back on our feet. We were in the ER with our two children and Medicare under the Affordable Care Act expansion made sure we didn't get more bills that we couldn't afford. ‚ÄúI've survived ovarian cancer three times. Here's why: I have great healthcare. Every Republican repeal and replace plan would leave me defenseless. I'm not saying I deserve to live. But I don't deserve to be abandoned. Believe me, cancer changes a person: I have used every single day of my remission to make a difference. I changed my career and now work with cancer survivors to give them hope. This is hard enough when we're just talking about how to survive the illness ‚Äî let alone how to fight down the panic of knowing your insurance is waiting to throw you under the bus. That's what repeal and replace comes down to. It really means repeal my peace of mind and replace the endless streams of money to ‚Äòcaregivers‚Äô who don't care. When it comes to cancer, there's no alien ‚Äòthey‚Äô who don't deserve care. Cancer is too common. Cancer is ‚Äòwe.‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄîAnne from Los Angeles

Sixty years ago today, nine Black students paved the way by integrating an all-white school following the Brown v. Board of Education decision that banned segregation. On their first day of school, the Little Rock Nine were escorted past an angry mob by federal troops to start their first day at Little Rock Central High. As the school year went on, they would endure violent threats, harassment, and even have acid thrown on them. The courage and bravery they embodied would pave the way for desegregation at schools, but the struggle they endured still persists today. Let us use today as a reminder that we must address the disparities in education for students of color.

‚ÄúFive years ago, I was diagnosed with stage 4 melanoma, a week after turning 39. I had five tumors ‚Äî one in my leg, two in my intestine, one in my lung, and one in my brain. I had multiple surgeries, radiation on my brain, and was treated with infusions of immunotherapy. I had excellent doctors because California has excellent doctors. Thank God, at that time, I was lucky. I had just signed up for the Affordable Care Act insurance, and I started a job three weeks before my first hospitalization. So I was covered. But what worries me is the future.

I currently see my oncologist every three months, alternating scans of my body and brain for any sign that my melanoma ‚Äî a notoriously tricky, resilient, and deadly cancer when caught at stage 4 ‚Äî has come back. If I face lifetime limits on my insurance, if I have to pay out of a health care savings account, if I'm put in an expensive high-risk pool or am placed on cut-rate insurance because I have a pre-existing condition, I'm done for. I cannot pay for it. My family cannot (even with insurance, sophisticated surgeries are expensive!). I'm asking you, please, as my representative, fight with everything you've got ‚Äî as we, the sick, do.‚Äù .
‚ÄîJustine from Los Angeles
Reforming our bail system is about economic justice.

‚ÄúAfter graduating college ten years ago, I was without health coverage. I developed appendicitis and had to have surgery. It was that, or die. I had my student loan debt and accumulated new health care debt. It cost over $14,000 to make sure I did not die from appendicitis. I now have a full-time job with health benefits that I pay for and I am lucky for that. I can pay my part. We need to provide coverage to everyone. No one should have to second guess debt in exchange for life.‚Äù ‚ÄîDavid from Cortland

‚ÄúMy daughter was born with severe hydrocephalus. No one knows why. I did all the things a pregnant mom is supposed to do to take care of her growing child. She had brain surgery at one day old to place a shunt. Within a month she needed it replaced. At 14 months her shunt failed again with catastrophic consequences ‚Äî severe brain injury. On this day in 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act into law, to guarantee African Americans the right to vote. It was later amended to expand protections. However, in 2013, the U.S. Supreme Court gutted a key section of this act. It‚Äôs critical that Congress work to update and reinvigorate the vital protections of this act and ensure our fundamental voting rights are protected for everyone. The battle for voting rights continues.
Two-thirds of minimum wage workers are women. For many, the federal minimum wage of $7.25 isn‚Äôt enough to keep a roof overhead and food on the table. #RaiseTheWage

We know that for far too many people ‚Äúliberty and justice for all‚Äù is a promise we have yet to keep. Some may want to turn their backs on the rights of workers to organize for their families and their futures. But we know better ‚Äî workers deserve a living wage and benefits. All Americans deserve health care. It should be a right for all, not a privilege for a few. And in order to make this a more perfect union, every child deserves access to quality public education and every parent should have access to affordable childcare. Together, let‚Äôs fight for that more perfect union where we don‚Äôt sink our college students with a lifetime of debt just so big banks and for-profit colleges can bathe in the riches. Together, we must fight for our ideals and push for real, meaningful progress.

Women made up the majority of calls to Congress during the health care fight, demanding to be heard. It‚Äôs clear: women won‚Äôt back down.

63 cents on the dollar ‚Äî that‚Äôs how much Black women are paid on the dollar compared to white, non-Hispanic men. Today on Black Women‚Äôs Equal Pay Day, we recognize that black women must work nearly twenty months just to earn the same amount white men earned in twelve months. That‚Äôs unacceptable. If we don‚Äôt act now, this gap won‚Äôt close in our lifetime.

On this day in 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed Medicare and Medicaid into law. We must continue to honor his vision by strengthening and expanding, not slashing, these initiatives that help millions of Americans.

Earlier this week, I joined my Senate Democratic colleagues in calling for a ban of chlorpyrifos. Under the current administration, the pesticide was green-lighted for use, despite the fact it has been found to cause brain damage in children. This is detrimental to human health.

The takeaway from the vote early this morning is not only to be relieved that millions of Americans are no longer at risk of losing their health care, but that you can make a difference. I couldn‚Äôt be more proud of the work this community put in to share your stories and to save our health care. Your voices made a difference in this fight. There was never a day where you weren‚Äôt speaking out for those with the most to lose. We proved this is what a democracy looks like. Let‚Äôs use this victory and keep showing up on so many other issues, including climate change, education, women‚Äôs rights, and criminal justice reform. Never lose hope. Your voice matters.
Tonight health care was saved for millions of Americans. This is your victory. Your calls, letters, and courage made this possible.

This adorable little girl is Emerson. Like many six-year-old girls, she loves to read, ride her bike, swim, go to school, and ride horses. Unlike most other six-year-olds, Emerson has cerebral palsy, epilepsy, and chronic lung disease after having a complicated birth. She can‚Äôt walk, talk, sit, or stand without assistance and needs multiple medications daily to keep her breathing, her muscles calm, and keep seizures away. Emerson will be starting first grade this year, and thanks to the Affordable Care Act and Medi-Cal, she is learning at grade level and continuing to achieve every day. I wanted to share Emerson‚Äôs story with you because we need to fight for children like her. I hope you won‚Äôt give up your calls to protect health care: (202) 224‚Äì3121.

‚ÄúMy daughter Natalie is 4 years old and loves swimming, drawing, and cooking. She was also born with osteogenesis imperfecta, otherwise known as brittle bones disease which requires careful management. Natalie has titanium rods in her femurs that allow her to stand and walk. She also needs medication every three months to strengthen her bones, which requires three days in the hospital for an infusion. Under the Affordable Care Act, insurance companies cannot refuse to sell us insurance and they cannot charge higher premiums for our coverage. The proposed health care changes would result in de facto segregation by health status. Our daughter would lose her affordable care.‚Äù ‚ÄîJoe from Santa Clara

‚ÄúMy son, now three, was diagnosed with an atrial septal defect at one years old, and had open-heart surgery at 19 months old. He is the most remarkable human ‚Äî the sweetest, most resilient little boy who falls down and pops up with "I'm ok" before you even have a moment to ask. He recently asked his preschool teacher if she wanted a seat on the couch because "she has a baby in her tummy." Annual or lifetime caps would be devastating to families who have congenital heart conditions. Please save our health care.‚Äù ‚ÄîGabrielle from Los Angeles

There is nothing ‚Äúskinny‚Äù about this new repeal bill the Republicans are considering. It will result in 16 million additional people without insurance by 2021 and result in premiums going up 20% next year. Families cannot afford it. Throughout the day today, I‚Äôll be sharing stories of children who rely on quality health care. Their stories deserve to be heard in this process, even if they can‚Äôt speak up for themselves. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚ÄúOur son Zeke was born with hemophilia, a bleeding disorder that makes it difficult for his blood to clot. He is dependent on a synthetic version of factor 8, a protein that healthy bodies produce naturally to help blood clot. This medicine costs $11,000. My husband and I both work full time but we simply cannot afford that amount. Without his medicine which he receives through Medicaid, Zeke will become disabled or in the worst case scenario, die. We plead with you to vote NO.‚Äù ‚ÄîDevalina from Philadelphia

Yesterday, Republicans voted to move forward to debate a bill that would strip away health care from millions of Americans. While their first attempt to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act failed, it‚Äôs the vote later this week that we need everyone to speak out against. This fight is far from over and the last thing we should do is despair or throw our hands up‚Ää. A lot of you have asked how you can help the fight if you live in a state with two Democratic Senators. First, reach out to friends and family in states with Senators who voted in favor of the motion to proceed. Make sure they‚Äôre calling and writing their Senators to protest the bill. Second, join any and all protests against this health care bill. Use your voice to show Republicans that we won‚Äôt go silently, we will fight for health care with all of our might because health care is a right, not a privilege. Third, tell your story, just like I‚Äôm going to keep sharing the stories people have shared with me. Time to redouble our efforts and keep up the work.

‚ÄúI was 19 years old when I was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. My freshman year in college at UC Santa Cruz, I was losing weight for no reason, and was thirsty and tired all the time. By the time I got to the hospital my blood sugar numbers were over 1000. I was very close to coma stage. 
As soon as I came off my mother's insurance at 24, the battle for my life began. I would get all the way to the end of insurance applications and as soon as I would get to the pre-existing condition category, I would be denied. Because of the years of back and forth I have developed two complications from diabetes: neuropathy (nerve damage in my legs and feet) and gastroparesis (nerve damage in my stomach causing ultra slow digestion). It was not until Obama was in office that the pre-existing discrimination wore off a bit. Even now with the Affordable Care Act, I still have to fight for necessity medicine and management tools that I need to stay alive so I cannot imagine anything that is going backward. It is a business decision for them and a death sentence for me.‚Äù ‚ÄîNiketa from Los Angeles

‚ÄúI am a native Californian, healthy all my life until age 54, when a shocking diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia halted my pleasant life. Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, I've had eight months of chemotherapy followed by a stem cell transplant. While my leukemia is currently in check, the treatment left me permanently disabled with chronic lung disease. I am dependent on monthly pulmonary appointments and many medications for my survival. Losing my coverage would mean losing my life. It is inexcusable that my family and I have to fight not just this illness, but for my health care. I expect the people we elect to work for our interests, not those of insurance companies.‚Äù ‚ÄîNancy from Marin

Republicans have a vote on health care planned for Tuesday. That means we have two more days to mobilize and make our voices heard about their disastrous bill. Their health care bill is not about making people‚Äôs lives better: it‚Äôs about tax cuts and trying to put money in the pockets of the top 1% and corporations. What we have to do in the next two days is continue this journey, arm in arm, and stand up for the voiceless and vulnerable. We can‚Äôt stop and we won‚Äôt stop keeping up the pressure on health care. Make those calls: (202) 224-3121.

‚ÄúI have been relatively healthy throughout my life, but at 65, my mom‚Äôs had 32 surgeries including three hip replacements and 12 knee surgeries. The Affordable Care Act allowed her to get the care she needed and not be concerned with whether she would have enough for a rehab clinic so she could walk again. She's the single most important person in my life, and because she can get quality medical assistance, I'll get to have my mom walk me down the aisle with my father at my wedding in 2019.‚Äù ‚ÄîKiera from Kings
Text FEARLESS to 225568 to stay up-to-date on what‚Äôs happening with health care, criminal justice reform, and more.

‚ÄúOur first child, Jacob, was born with Down syndrome. He spent three and a half weeks in the neonatal intensive care unit because of feeding issues. We brought him home days before Christmas but he returned back to the hospital at nine and a half weeks. He had holes in his heart and needed open heart surgery. My son did nothing wrong, he didn't ask for this! He didn't live an unhealthy lifestyle, he was not reckless. He is the strongest person I know. He depends on Medicaid for services he receives at home and at public school. I don't understand how all of these pro-life politicians can turn their backs once these beautiful babies are born. Cuts to Medicaid and lifetime caps on insurance are unthinkable to me! I don't know what our family would do.‚Äù ‚ÄîNicolle from Los Angeles

"I have been living with Type 1 Diabetes since the age of 12. This is a very expensive autoimmune disease that requires 24/7 attention, and has no cure. I rely heavily on my insurance to afford the sophisticated medical supplies and insulin I need in order to live. Two years ago when I was just 26, I was diagnosed with Ovarian Cancer. While I lost my right ovary, I was lucky to have caught it in an early stage and have been cancer free since January of 2016. I fear that if protections for people with pre-existing conditions are revoked, I will either be unable to afford insurance or completely uninsurable at all due to these two serious conditions. The sorry excuse of a health bill that the senate is trying to pass has nothing to do with healthcare ‚Äî it's simply an excuse to further line the pockets of the wealthiest Americans. Please keep fighting for the many people like me who deserve access to affordable care. We deserve to live.‚Äù ‚ÄîMonica from Alameda

‚ÄúMy son was born with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. It is a rare connective tissue disorder. He is prone to dislocations and has fragile skin that takes months to heal from the smallest scratch. My son lives with chronic pain. It took six and a half years, multiple trips to geneticists and other specialists, before he finally received a diagnosis. My son currently sees seven specialists plus has weekly physical therapy and occupational therapy appointments. If he has a good year, he will have 56 appointments. I always worry that we are one injury away from financial ruin and I am fearful that due to his medical diagnosis, he will be uninsurable under Trumpcare.‚Äù ‚ÄîNate from San Bernardino

At the Women Unshackled forum yesterday I talked about how I visited the Central California Women‚Äôs Facility a few weeks ago. And something that I was reminded of there was the concept of redemption. We will all make mistakes, and for some of us, that mistake will rise to the level of being a crime. And yes, there must be accountability and consequence. But is it not the sign of a civil society that we allow people the chance to earn their way back? That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so critical that we work on providing resources to improve reentry. We should be smarter.

Earlier today, I spoke at the Women Unshackled forum on female incarceration. We‚Äôve been offered a false choice about the criminal justice system. We are either tough on crime or soft on crime ‚Äî I say we need to be smart on crime.

The health care fight isn‚Äôt over until the bill is dead. That‚Äôs why I was at Upper Senate Park earlier today, showing Republicans that we won‚Äôt stop the pressure for quality health care. As a country we have to ask ourselves: Do we believe health care should be a right for all, or a privilege for the few? I say a right for all.

‚ÄúI was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 12 years ago, breast cancer five years ago, and have had numerous skin cancers cut out. I would not be able to go to the doctors or buy medication if it wasn't for the Affordable Care Act! I had to retire on disability from my teaching job, and it was only financially possible because of the ACA.‚Äù ‚ÄîPatricia from San Diego

My colleagues and I recently wrote a letter to the Secretary of Education, Betsy DeVos, urging the Department of Education to strengthen services to those struggling to repay their student loans and work with Congress to create a better system for borrowers.

After visiting a female correctional facility last week, it‚Äôs clear we must ensure all inmates maintain a level of dignity and respect. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm proud to cosponsor the Dignity for Incarcerated Women Act with Senators Warren, Booker, and Durbin.

This is seven-year-old Myka. After she was born, she remained in the NICU for two weeks and has had two open heart surgeries. Before she turned one, Myka and her family had approximately $500,000 in medical costs. Myka‚Äôs mom wrote to me, asking me to protect her daughter from any bill that would deny her health coverage. I want her to know that my Democratic colleagues and I won‚Äôt give up trying to protect and strengthen our nation‚Äôs health care system, no matter what the other side throws our way. And to everyone out there, I hope you won‚Äôt give up the calls to protect Myka and so many other children like her: (202) 224‚Äì3121.

Last week I held a roundtable discussion with agricultural leaders and farmers. The work that‚Äôs happening in our state has a global impact, which is why it‚Äôs so important we have these conversations to ensure their issues are being addressed in Washington.
Each and every day we must get out of bed and continue to fight for truth, justice, and a government that is accountable to the public.

‚ÄúMy 13-year-old daughter has a rare mitochondrial disorder. She has had six surgeries, including two pacemakers, in the past three years. She has bilateral cochlear implants, poor coordination which will require an assistive walking device in the near future, and poor appetite/weight gain which will require a feeding tube soon. The disease is progressive and affects every major organ system in some way. Without the protection of insurance companies not being able to exclude pre-existing conditions and no cap on the maximum lifetime benefits, her health care expenses will become unmanageable. We have great health insurance and have never been denied any medically necessary procedures. This will certainly change if the Affordable Care Act is repealed.‚Äù ‚ÄîChristina from Tarrant

‚ÄúIn June of 2016, my husband was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia and admitted to UCLA Medical Center. Two weeks later, I found a lump on my shoulder which turned out to be non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. I had surgery, chemo, and radiation while he had transfusions and weekly treatments. We were fortunate to have Medicare and my health insurance with my employer. My husband passed away in April after two month-long stays at UCLA. I am hopefully in remission, but at 72 years old, I am terrified to retire as this new health care bill may eliminate my pre-existing condition exemption, and I know Medicare alone will leave lots of bills if I relapse. I would be in terrible financial shape if not for the coverage we received for my husband and myself.‚Äù ‚ÄîKathy from Ventur
#FlashbackFriday to primary night in 2016. We‚Äôve come a long way since then. üì∑: Justin Buell

‚ÄúMy daughter has autism and epilepsy. Prior to the Affordable Care Act, my employer‚Äôs insurance denied her therapies because autism was not a covered diagnosis and therapy was ‚Äòhabilitative.‚Äô The ACA changed this. At 6, she still is nonverbal, but is learning sign language and how to communicate with a device. She starts kindergarten this fall, and has an amazing team to help her grow and learn. As a mom, I am so scared the resources which are protected by the ACA and provided by Medicaid will go away. My daughter has no voice, so I am her voice in this fight. She is young and her needs will last a lifetime. They cannot be at risk every time the party in power changes. Please don't play politics with those who need it most.‚Äù ‚ÄîBethany from Maricopa

‚ÄúI am 67-years-old and I suffer from hypothyroidism, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. I have Medicare but a lot of my meds and co-pays I cannot afford, which is where Medicaid kicks in. At this time everything is under control, but if I lose Medicaid, I don't know what I would do. Also, my mom has Alzheimer's and is in a nursing home. What will happen to her?‚Äù ‚ÄîRenell from Bronx

Today we celebrate the independence of our great country and all that we stand for. I hope you have the chance to spend the day with friends and family, honor those who have and currently serve, and recommit yourself to the fight against injustice in all forms.

‚ÄúSix years ago I donated a kidney to an unknown recipient, saving the insurance companies tens of thousands of dollars in dialysis and other related costs. Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, I've been able to monitor the health of my remaining kidney but under the newly proposed Republican bill, my donation would likely be considered a pre-existing condition. When I donated a kidney my goal was merely to improve the life of another human being who was suffering. I underwent a multitude of thorough tests to determine that I was in excellent health. Kidney donors are some of the healthiest people on the planet and yet under the new bill would be lumped together with sick people paying high premiums and having ridiculous deductibles. I never expected any reward or recognition for my donation, but I certainly didn't expect to be punished.‚Äù ‚ÄîE from San Luis Obispo

‚ÄúI have a congenital autoimmune disease which is destroying my connective tissue and my nervous tissue. It is very painful and a pre-existing condition. Without healthcare insurance, my prescriptions would cost $10,000.00 a month. This is three times my income and more than my wife's income. I would die.‚Äù ‚ÄîJim from Alameda

‚ÄúOur son Michael is 44 and has cerebral palsy. He needs support with all activities of daily living. With the support he receives through MediCal and the Medicaid waiver, he is an active member of the community. This supports the shaped seating and his power wheelchair that help him be mobile, but avoid pressure sores. Without MediCal, his health will deteriorate and he could not participate in church, job skills training, or communicate with friends. He would probably be in pain and have a shorter life.‚Äù

Today marks the end of Pride Month, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we can stop fighting for the LGBTQ community. Rather, we must continue pursuing justice and equality during the other 11 months of the year. I had the rainbow flag placed outside my office in Washington this month to remind myself how far we‚Äôve come as a nation, but how much work we still have left to do.

‚ÄúWhen my wife and I moved from New York to California in late 2013, she was pregnant. Since we moved states, our New York health insurance no longer covered us in California and for 3 months until the Affordable Care Act started in 2014, we couldn't get insurance due to my wife's "pre-existing condition" ‚Äî that being her pregnancy. The baby finally came in late March 2014 and the hospital bill was $100,000. There is no way we could have afforded that. Without the Affordable Care Act the insurance companies can go back to disqualifying anyone they want from their healthcare. We cannot go back to that.‚Äù ‚ÄîDavid from Santa Clara

Was outside the U.S. Capitol to show the GOP we won‚Äôt stand by while they try to pass a bill that would leave 22M more Americans uninsured by 2026.

‚ÄúI went most of my life without knowing that my kidneys were failing. I found out right when my Covered California plan took hold. I was diagnosed with a preexisting condition at 30 years old. It seemed like my life was doomed. Now, at 32, I'm alive thanks to UCLA's kidney exchange program, my husband, my kidney donor, and the Affordable Care Act. I don't know where I would be today without the Affordable Care Act. But what scares me is that I don't know where I will be with Trumpcare.‚Äù ‚Ä¢
‚ÄîDenisse from Los Angeles

‚ÄúLike Mitch McConnell, I had polio. I was just three months of age and I was not expected to survive. If I did, the doctors said I would not even be able to sit up, or use my hands let alone walk. I did recover most of my upper strength but spent the first years of my life in the hospital, and endured painful surgeries, long term body and leg casts and difficult therapy throughout my childhood. Even so, I never was able to walk without crutches, and usually wore leg and back braces...I got a bad deal at a very young age and I have always dealt with it on my own and planned and saved so that I would be able to live with some comfort and dignity in my life. I did everything right and now I am a mean-spirited vote away from a very sad future and perhaps even a much earlier death than I would otherwise have, leaving my daughter alone at a young age. Please do not allow this to happen.‚Äù ‚ÄîMarilyn from Monterey

On June 26, 2015, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that the Constitution guarantees a right to marriage for all couples. In 2013, two years prior to the SCOTUS decision legalizing same-sex marriage nationwide, I was honored to marry Sandy Stier and Kris Perry after the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals lifted California's ban on same-sex marriages. That was an incredibly moving day. But that day in 2015 was truly a historic day because, for the first time in our nation‚Äôs history, every single American had the right to marry the person they love.

@EleniForCA is a powerful advocate for immigrants and has fought for affordable college education and health care for all throughout her life. I know she‚Äôll stand up and defend our values. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm proud to endorse Eleni for California Lt. Governor.

‚ÄúMy son was born with dwarfism. He has yearly visits with specialists to make sure he is healthy and has no issues. Without these visits he could lose his vision or even become paralyzed. All of this is preventable as long as any issues are discovered and treated early. The guarantee of insurance coverage for him gives us the peace of mind that he will maintain a good quality of life and grow to become a productive member of society.‚Äù ‚Äî Stacey from Ventura
#Throwback to San Francisco‚Äôs Pride Parade last year. Happy Pride everyone!

Facts and numbers are important, but we need to elevate your voices and make sure the GOP knows what‚Äôs at stake ‚Äî people‚Äôs lives. Share your health care story with me: kamalaharris.org/acastory
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúMy grandmother passed away before she turned 60 from breast cancer. My aunt had it for a while. If either my mother or I get it, it would be considered a preexisting condition. Without affordable treatment, it would not be possible for us to fight cancer and win. Why don't we have enough female representation in these types of healthcare deliberations?‚Äù ‚ÄîB from San Francisco

‚ÄúIn November of 2016, I received one of the worst diagnoses a woman can get: breast cancer. But thanks to Covered California, I'm able to get the quality medical care I need ‚Äî without suffering financial harm. Thank God for the Affordable Care Act! As a 59-year old tax paying citizen who has worked for the last 43 years, I should not have to risk losing my health insurance because the premiums have skyrocketed due to my "pre-existing condition." That's what this terrible new GOP health care plan does to me and millions of others. Why does Congress protect its own from the cruel health care changes it's inflicting on hardworking Americans? How can this be our America?‚Äù ‚ÄîBarb, San Diego

Gilbert Baker, designer of the rainbow flag, created a symbol of pride for the LGBT movement. Born in Kansas, Gilbert served in the Army and was stationed in San Francisco. After he was honorably discharged, he stayed in San Francisco and taught himself how to sew. Gilbert used his skills to create banners for anti-war and gay rights marches. He created the rainbow flag in 1978 and refused to trademark it because he wanted it to belong to the entire LGBT community. The original flag had eight colors, each representing a different aspect of humanity: pink for sexuality, red for life, orange for healing, yellow for the sun, green for nature, turquoise for magic, blue for serenity, and purple for the spirit. Until his death earlier this year, Gilbert never stopped creating flags and advocating for the gay community. #PrideMonth
There are more women in the Senate than ever before. It‚Äôs a start, but that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so important that we reelect my Democratic colleagues in 2018.

Over the next couple of days, I‚Äôm going to share stories of those who have benefited from the Affordable Care Act. It‚Äôs wrong that the GOP wants to push this bill through without bipartisan input. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúMy daughter was born with a blood disorder called Hereditary Spherocytosis. It was a random gene mutation. She will have it for the rest of her life. She is 5 years old and has a pre-existing condition.‚Äù ‚ÄîJ from San Diego.

Happy birthday to two dear colleagues of mine: Senators Dianne Feinstein and @elizabethwarrenma. Your work in the Senate each and every day betters lives not only in California and Massachusetts, but also across the entire nation. #TBT

Kye Allums was the first openly transgender NCAA Division I athlete. Born and raised in Minnesota, Kye came out when he was playing on the women‚Äôs basketball team at George Washington University in 2010. After graduating, Kye parlayed his career into advocacy work and is now a public speaker, mentor to LGBT youth, and a transgender advocate. He travels the country speaking to college students, sharing his experiences. #PrideMonth

Yesterday I joined my Democratic colleagues to hold the Senate floor to express our outrage that we have not seen the health care repeal bill. I spoke out for people like Steve Martin, an Affordable Care Act beneficiary. When the Affordable Care Act was up for debate it went through 106 public hearings, incorporated more than 170 Republican amendments, and the entire process took a year. Now the Republicans are hoping to vote on this bill next week. The lack of transparency and bipartisanship is outrageous.

These past few weeks have stressed to me how important it is that we continue to make our voices heard. We face a proposed budget from the administration that will dramatically harm services for women, children, and families. We face a bill that would take away health coverage for 23 million Americans. We face an administration that wants to undo the progress we‚Äôve made on combating climate change. Because everyone benefits when you are heard.

Jim Obergefell is the named plaintiff in the Supreme Court case ‚ÄúObergefell v. Hodges,‚Äù which legalized same-sex marriage nationwide. Born and raised in Ohio, Jim came out as gay to his family in his 20s. In 1992, he met his future husband, John Arthur. The two fell in love and in 2011, John was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig‚Äôs disease. Jim and John wanted to become legally married but since same-sex marriage wasn‚Äôt legal in Ohio, they traveled to Maryland, where same-sex marriage was legal. 
Three months after their wedding, John passed away. Before his death, the couple filed a lawsuit to force Ohio to recognize Jim as the surviving spouse on John‚Äôs death certificate. Though a federal judge ruled in favor of Jim, the state of Ohio challenged this ruling and won. So Jim took his case to the Supreme Court. In 2015, thanks to Jim‚Äôs courageous fight, the Supreme Court ruled in Jim‚Äôs favor and stated that the Constitution does indeed protect the right to same-sex marriage. #PrideMonth
#TBT to 2008 with Senator Feinstein. Who would have thought that one day we‚Äôd both be representing the great state of California together?

As the host of her own daytime talk show, Ellen Degeneres is one of America‚Äôs most well-known comedians and an outspoken activist for the LGBTQ community. Born in Louisiana, Ellen began to perform stand-up comedy when she was in her 20‚Äôs and got her big break after she appeared on The Tonight Show. In 1994, she starred in the prime-time sitcom, ‚ÄúEllen.‚Äù When Ellen came out as a lesbian, her character followed suit, becoming the first lead in sitcom history to come out on air. Throughout her career, Ellen has used her platform to speak out for LGBTQ rights and fight against injustices in the gay community. In November, Ellen was given the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Obama. #PrideMonth

Bayard Rustin, born in Pennsylvania, was the chief organizer of the March on Washington and a key adviser to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Growing up, he attended historically black schools and participated in numerous nonviolent protests, which eventually led him to become a human rights protest organizer. In the 1950‚Äôs, Bayard met Dr. King and began working with him as an organizer and strategist. An openly gay man, some regarded his sexuality as a liability to be associated with the high-profile March on Washington. Luckily, King expressed confidence in him, which led to one of the most well attended and well-organized marches. In 2013, Bayard was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom. #PrideMonth

Since President Trump has so far failed to nationally recognize June as Pride Month, I wanted to take some time this month to highlight members of the LGBTQ community who have dedicated their lives in pursuit of equality. Since Harvey Milk Day was last month, I wanted to share a little more about Harvey‚Äôs background ‚Üí 
Born in New York, Harvey joined the U.S. Navy where he served as a diving instructor at a base in San Diego. After moving to New York for a time, Harvey moved to San Francisco where he opened a camera shop in the heart of the city‚Äôs growing gay community. Having known since high school that he was gay, Harvey quickly found himself becoming a popular figure in the area. A year after he moved to the city, he declared his candidacy for the San Francisco Board of Supervisors. While he lost that race, it spurred him to keep trying. In 1977, Harvey made history when he was elected to San Francisco's Board of Supervisors ‚Äî becoming the first openly gay person elected to public office in California.

This week I visited the Port of Los Angeles and the Martin Luther King, Jr. Outpatient Center. Both of these places will be impacted by President Trump‚Äôs proposed budget cuts. The Port of Los Angeles, which supports nearly 500,000 jobs within local counties, faces cuts to port security and infrastructure development grants. The Outpatient Center, on the other hand, is a critical example of the Affordable Care Act working to combat the drug crisis. As the opioid epidemic gets worse, now is not the time to cut back on resources that address it. Ensuring both these places receive full funding is critical to our state.

Today is National Gun Violence Awareness Day. In 2013, 15-year-old Hadiya Pendleton was shot and killed in Chicago after being mistaken for a rival gang member. In order to raise awareness about the fight to end gun violence, her friends wore orange. Ever since then people across the country honor Hadiya and all the other victims of gun violence by wearing orange on what would have been Hadiya‚Äôs birthday. According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than 90 Americans are killed every day with guns. From universal background checks to getting weapons of war off our streets, there is much more we can do to end gun violence. #wearorange

‚ÄúI am a licensed professional counselor and one of my specialties is treatment for survivors of sexual trauma. Once a survivor has elected to seek treatment, continuing uninterrupted is critical to their recovery. A survivor needing care had to stop treatment in 2015 due to job loss. Because of the Affordable Care Act they were able to pick up coverage through the health care marketplace and resume their work in therapy.‚Äù ‚ÄîMonique from Frisco

"I am now a 45-year-old mother of three and going on five years post-diagnosis Colon Cancer survivor...Chemo saved my life but it also left me with severe nerve damage to my hands, feet and lower legs as well as memory and cognitive difficulties that are all permanent. I am no longer able to work as a corporate event manager, a career that I loved dearly. I was, and am, lucky to have very good health care through my husband's employer. The total cost for my hospital stay alone, paid for by insurance, was over one million dollars! How can we put any family ‚Äî without the kind of health care that we are lucky enough to have ‚Äî in a situation where they survive a horrific experience like that, just to lose everything they own due to lack of health care insurance?‚Äù *
‚ÄîGail from Sonoma

‚ÄúMy elder daughter, Julie, is a breast cancer survivor. She has been in remission for more than 5 years. As a father, I cannot help but wonder if it is gone for good. Without affordable health care, we could have lost her. I don't want her to ever go through that pain and mental anguish again.‚Äù ‚ÄîDavid from San Mateo

‚ÄúI have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. I have a nebulizer to take breathing treatments. I also use an inhaler. I have a pre-existing condition. Without insurance, I won't be able to afford my medication.‚Äù ‚ÄîCarla from Detroit

‚ÄúI have been a self-employed dance instructor for 42 years. I‚Äôve bought my own health insurance since the day I graduated from college. After many years of paying insurance rates, they started to go up and it became very difficult for me. When Obamacare came into place, it literally saved me. Business was not that great and I was just able to pay the bills with no savings in sight. I can actually go to the doctor when I need to without worrying about money. It has been the greatest blessing in my life to have Obamacare and to be able to seek well care visits etc... to stay healthy. Taking my healthcare away from me would be devastating at this point.‚Äù ‚ÄîDonna from Los Angeles

‚ÄúMy sister was diagnosed with three autoimmune disorders as a young adult: rheumatoid arthritis, narcolepsy, and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The drugs she takes for narcolepsy mean she can't ever be alone at night. If there were an emergency she wouldn't wake up. Her entire day is measured by the pain in her joints and her limited levels of energy. She didn't ask for any of this and there was nothing she could do to prevent it. One day it will probably be too difficult for her to work. Without employer provided insurance she will need insurance that covers her needs and one she can afford. She's got 5 nieces, a sister, a brother, a mom, a dad, a whole bunch of friends and a husband who love the snot out of her. Her health doesn‚Äôt determine one bit of her worth and value. Congress shouldn't treat her as if it did.‚Äù ‚ÄîJenny from San Diego

‚ÄúWho doesn't have pre-existing conditions by age 60? As we age, these things add up. I was lucky enough to have coverage and get life-saving treatment for ovarian and skin cancer in time. But if I'm denied access to health care because of these pre-existing conditions, my story will be over. Skin cancer kills quickly.‚Äù *
‚ÄîMartha from Sonoma

‚ÄúMy daughter was born extremely premature at only 24 weeks due to my ruptured appendix. She's overcome a brain bleed, multiple months on a ventilator, ROP, a hole in her heart, kidney issues and more. We are so blessed that she is now a mostly healthy two-year-old with chronic lung disease/asthma. She was basically born with a pre-existing condition. Should she be punished for that? Should we as her parents be punished? Should we have to choose between feeding her well, having her in a safe daycare, or her medications? Should I have to look to see how much is in the bank before I can take her to an appointment or the emergency room? My husband and I both work full time. We pay our taxes and we contribute to society. But our child was a million dollar baby (that's how much her medical expenses totaled by the time she left the hospital). I need to know that nothing will stop her from having the medical care she so deserves and needs.‚Äù *
‚ÄîTrish from San Diego

Yesterday, the Congressional Budget Office announced that under the GOP health care plan, there would be 23 million more uninsured Americans by 2026 than under current law. On this day in 1954, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that segregation in public schools was ‚Äúinherently unequal‚Äù and therefore, unconstitutional. This was a major day in our nation‚Äôs history and changed the course of our history and impacted the lives of many, including my own. Almost two decades after this landmark ruling, I was part of only the second class to integrate Berkeley public schools. Had the court ruled differently, I and many others across the nation, would not be where we are today. Sixty-three years later, it‚Äôs critical we reflect on Brown v. Board and how we can continue to close the educational disparities that still exist today. üì∑: Thomas J. O'Halloran

From employment discrimination cases to cases about birth control, Judge Gorsuch has consistently sided with corporations. On the last day of Women‚Äôs History Month I want to recognize my mother, Shyamala Harris. My mother was born in India and came to the United States to study at UC Berkeley, where she eventually became an endocrinologist and breast-cancer researcher. She, and so many other strong women in my life, showed me the importance of community involvement and public service. #WomensHistoryMonth

Today, on C√©sar Ch√°vez Day, we celebrate the life and legacy of the great labor leader and civil rights activist. Born in Arizona, C√©sar later moved to California and worked in the fields where he experienced meager wages for backbreaking labor and corrupt contractors. These experiences propelled C√©sar to fighting for improved treatment, pay, and conditions for farm workers. In 1962, he founded the National Farm Workers Association which would later become the United Farm Workers. During his lifetime, he participated in numerous boycotts and fasts to protest worker conditions.

Malala Yousafzai is an activist and the youngest-ever Nobel Prize laureate. Born in Pakistan, Malala spoke out after the Taliban called for the ending of education for women and girls. She was determined to go to school and raised her voice against this injustice both in person and online. In 2012, while seated on a bus heading home from school, two members of the Taliban boarded the bus and shot Malala. Miraculously, she survived and become a global advocate for giving women and girls around the world access to quality education. Malala has also spoke at the United Nations, write a book, and won the Nobel Peace Prize. "There are two powers in the world; one is the sword and the other is the pen. There is a third power stronger than both, that of women." #WomensHistoryMonth
#TBT with my friends and colleagues @RepMaxineWaters and @RepJohnLewis ‚Äî don't mess with them! #squadgoals

Sally Yates was the first woman to be named U.S. attorney for the Northern District of Georgia and recently became a household name after she said the Justice Department wouldn‚Äôt defend President Trump‚Äôs Muslim ban. Born in Atlanta, Sally grew up with law in her blood as her grandma was one of the first women admitted to the Georgia Bar and her father was a judge on the Georgia Court of Appeals. She received her law degree from the University of Georgia School of Law, where she was the executive editor of the Georgia Law Review. Sally started working at the Department of Justice in 1989, before moving up to become Deputy Attorney General where she was responsible for the day-to-day operations of the 13,000-employee Justice Department. #WomensHistoryMonth

@serenawilliams is the winner of 23 Grand Slam singles titles. Born in Michigan but raised in California, Serena began playing tennis when she was three. Serena‚Äôs father, a former sharecropper, taught her and her sister Venus the game on courts not far from the family‚Äôs new home in Compton. By the time she was ten, she was ranked first in her age division on the junior United States Tennis Association tour. A few years later Serena turned pro and went on to earn numerous achievements, including a Career Grand Slam. 
Off the court, Serena and Venus were the first black women to hold an ownership stake in an NFL franchise. Furthermore, Serena launched a clothing and accessories line called the Signature Statement collection and has created The Serena Williams Fund to promote equality in education and support positive change within communities. #WomensHistoryMonth

Judge Gorsuch‚Äôs record shows he is willing to favor corporations over the American people. From imposing religious views on employees to outright hostility toward workers, he has a history of rulings that directly hurt middle class families, consumers, women, and more. For this reason, I oppose his nomination.
