Unfortunately, there are a number damaging lines in President Trump‚Äôs budget, including his cuts to the National Institutes of Health, a leader in America‚Äôs cancer fight. It‚Äôs clear that we need to completely overhaul Trump‚Äôs budget blueprint so it's in line with the needs of Californians.

My colleague, Senator Tammy Duckworth, is an Iraq War Veteran and Purple Heart recipient. Tammy attended the University of Hawaii before moving to Illinois to pursue a Ph.D. In 2004, she was deployed to Iraq as a Black Hawk helicopter pilot when her helicopter was hit by an RPG. Tammy lost her legs and partial use of her right arm but that hasn‚Äôt held her back. She became an advocate for veterans at both the state and federal level before being elected to the House of Representatives. She now serves alongside me as Senator from Illinois. #WomensHistoryMonth

Runner Marla Runyan was the first legally blind person to compete in the Olympic Games. Born in California, she developed Stargardt‚Äôs Disease at age nine which left her legally blind. Marla started playing sports when she was just 3 years old, including gymnastics, swimming, and soccer, but when she could no longer see the soccer ball she began focusing on track. Marla showed the world that you can be blind and be an accomplished runner, becoming a three-time national 5,000-meter champion and finishing fourth in the 2002 New York City Marathon in 2:27:10. #WomensHistoryMonth

Today on the seventh anniversary of the Affordable Care Act, the House Republicans are voting to kick millions of people off their health insurance. The Republican plan will increase costs for seniors, slash $900 billion to Medicaid, all while cutting taxes for the wealthy. Health care is a right, not a privilege. I cannot stress enough the importance of calling your representatives at (202) 224-3121 and telling them to oppose this bill.

Last week, we asked how President Trump‚Äôs proposed budget would affect you and your family. A budget is a reflection of our values as a nation. It should protect the most vulnerable in our society while investing in the future of our country. Trump‚Äôs proposed budget does the exact opposite. This week I‚Äôll highlight the stories of those who will be hurt most by the budget outlined by the White House.

Before there was Rosa Parks, there was Claudette Colvin. Growing up in Montgomery, Alabama, Claudette was fifteen when she refused to move to the back of the bus and give up her seat to a white passenger. Police officers came and dragged her off the bus, charging her with disorderly conduct and defying the segregation law. She would go on to become one of four plaintiffs in Browder v. Gayle, which found the town‚Äôs segregated bus system was unconstitutional. #WomensHistoryMonth

Misty Copeland began ballet at age 13 ‚Äî considered late for ballerinas to begin. She took her first ballet class on a basketball court for free while visiting a Boys and Girls Club in San Pedro, California while she and her family were living in a motel. Misty applied to numerous top ballet companies but kept getting rejected because she was told she had the wrong body for ballet. In 2000, Misty‚Äôs big break came when she was chosen to join the American Ballet Theatre's Studio Company. #WomensHistoryMonth

Sylvia Mendez, a civil rights activist, was born in Orange County, California. Back in 1943, students of Mexican descent were required to attend separate schools from Caucasian children. After her family discovered the all-white school provided a better education, they tried to enroll Sylvia in that school but was initially denied admission. Her father took the case to court and a victorious outcome made Sylvia the first student of Mexican descent to attend a segregated all-white school in California, paving the way for California to become the first state in the nation to end segregation in schools. This victory also set precedent for other cases, including Brown v. Board of Education. In 2011, President Barack Obama awarded Sylvia the Presidential Medal of Freedom. #WomensHistoryMonth

Michelle K. Lee developed a love for technology at an early age, even building her own television as a child. Born in California, she received her J.D. from Stanford Law School. Prior to Michelle‚Äôs public service as the first woman and first person of color to lead the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, she advised tech companies like Google on issues relating to legal, business, and technical matters. Michelle‚Äôs work has inspired many women and teaches all of us the importance of STEM. #WomensHistoryMonth
Thank you @mindyprojecthulu and @TheEllenShow for showing that representation in leadership matters.

Nancy Lopez, the daughter of an auto mechanic, started playing golf at age eight and won her first amateur golf tournament by the time she was 12. She played golf during college but left after her sophomore year to turn pro. This move would work in her favor, as Nancy would be named LPGA Player of the Year as a rookie. Thrust into the spotlight as she kept winning, people who usually paid little attention to women‚Äôs golf suddenly became fascinated with the sport. She would go on to win 48 LPGA titles, be inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame, and become the only woman to win LPGA Rookie of the Year, Player of the Year, and the Vare Trophy in the same season. #WomensHistoryMonth

Constance Baker Motley, a civil rights activist, lawyer, and judge, inspired me from a young age to want to be a lawyer and fight for the voiceless and for justice. An avid reader as a child, she decided at age 15 that she wanted to pursue legal studies after reading books about black history. After graduating from New York University, she attended Columbia Law School. Constance helped write briefs in Brown v. Board of Education and would later go on to become the first black woman to argue a case before the U.S. Supreme Court. Throughout her life, she represented the Freedom Fighters, fought for Dr. King‚Äôs right to march in Albany, Georgia, and played a key role in representing black men and women who were seeking admission to Southern universities. "The work I'm doing now will affect people's lives intimately," she said in a New York Times interview in 1977, "it may even change them." #WomensHistoryMonth

Under the GOP health care replacement plan, the number of uninsured Americans would rise by 24 million by 2026. As one of the most populated states  the union, Californians would especially be harmed by the repeal and replace of the Affordable Care Act.

Madam C.J. Walker‚Äôs entrepreneurial spirit led her to become America‚Äôs first female millionaire. Born in Louisiana, Madam C.J. Walker was the first in her family to be free-born, as both her parents were recently freed slaves. At the age of 7, she became an orphan and went to live with her sister where she picked cotton. After Madam C.J. Walker developed a scalp disorder that caused her to lose her hair, she started to look at different remedies to improve her condition before eventually developing different hair care products. Recognizing many black women were experiencing the same hair problems as she was, she opened up businesses around the United States that promoted hair-care and cosmetics. Besides being a businesswoman, Madam C.J. Walker was also a philanthropist and social activist. #WomensHistoryMonth

@ibtihajmuhammad, an internationally ranked saber fencer, made history in Rio as the first U.S. woman to compete in the Rio Olympic Games in a hijab. Born in New Jersey, Ibtihaj started fencing when she was just 13 because as a Muslim woman, the sport didn‚Äôt require her to alter the uniform. Recruited to fence at Duke University, she became a three-time All-American and the 2005 Junior Olympic Champion. During the Summer 2016 Rio Olympics, Ibtihaj earned a bronze medal as part of Team USA, becoming the first female Muslim American to earn an Olympic medal. #WomensHistoryMonth
Happy Pi Day to all the mathematicians and pie lovers out there! #PiDay

Attending school in the earliest years is critical to students‚Äô success later in life. Kids that miss school are at a higher risk of dropping out of school and are more likely enter into the criminal justice system. That‚Äôs why, as California‚Äôs Attorney General, I created the Bureau of Children‚Äôs Justice to focus on elementary school attendance. Eliminating elementary school truancy was one of my top priorities as California‚Äôs Attorney General and continues to be one of my priorities today. With better monitoring and communication with parents, we can continue to ensure students are in school and have the opportunity to reach their full potential.

Simone Biles is the most decorated American gymnast ‚Äî male or female ‚Äî of all time, winning nineteen Olympic and World Championship medals. Born in Columbus, Ohio, she was raised by her grandparents due to her mother‚Äôs struggles with drug and alcohol addiction. After a field trip to a gym when she was six years old, Simone came home with a note suggesting her family enroll her in gymnastics lessons. They did, and Simone went on to set an American record for most gold medals in women‚Äôs gymnastics in a single Olympic Games during the 2016 Summer Rio games. It was during that time that Simone would help lead the ‚ÄúFinal Five‚Äù women‚Äôs gymnastics team to gold. #WomensHistoryMonth

Justice Sonia Sotomayor became the first Latina Supreme Court Justice in our nation‚Äôs history in 2009. She grew up in the Bronx and became inspired to go into law after watching a legal drama television series. She attended college at Princeton University before going to Yale Law School, where she became an editor of the Yale Law Journal. After being confirmed to serve on the Supreme Court, the the first case she heard was Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, where she opposed unlimited rights for corporations in politics.¬† Since then, she has continued to fight for the constitutional rights of Americans. #WomensHistoryMonth

Actress, singer, and songwriter @cynthiaerivo won the Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical for her starring role in "The Color Purple: The Musical." Born in London and raised by a single mother, Cynthia started acting at age 11. It wasn‚Äôt until she was studying music psychology in college that she was persuaded to transfer to the prestigious Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts. Her ability to bring the characters she plays to life has made her the recipient of countless awards. In 2017, she won Best Musical Theatre Album at the Grammy Awards. #WomensHistoryMonth
Photo by @msayles

Kalpana Chawla was the first Indian American woman to visit space. Originally from India, she moved to America to obtain her Master of Science degree in aerospace engineering. She would later go on to earn her PhD from the University of Colorado. The same year Kalpana graduated, she began working for NASA on computational fluid dynamics research. In 1994, she was selected as an astronaut candidate and three years later, she went into space aboard the Columbia shuttle as a mission specialist and robotic arm operator. Kalpana‚Äôs second voyage into space would be her final mission. In 2003, she was on board when the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster occurred. Kalpana‚Äôs untimely death was a tragic loss for the world and she was posthumously awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor. #WomensHistoryMonth

Today is International Women‚Äôs Day and #ADayWithoutAWoman, an opportunity to recognize the progress we've made and acknowledge how far we have to go to achieve full equality. Imagine what a day without women would mean:

Imagine a day without Harriet Tubman or Dolores Huerta. Imagine a day without Shirley Chisholm or Maya Angelou. Imagine a day without Ruth Bader Ginsburg or Constance Baker Motley. Imagine a day without Ibtihaj Muhammad or Serena Williams. Imagine a day without Aung Sang Suu Kyi or Malala Yousafzai.

We stand on the shoulders of the women who came before us as well as the women who are marching in the streets for our civil rights. Today and every day, I stand with all women. I will keep fighting for you.

Dolores Huerta, an American labor leader and civil rights activist, has fought for the social and economic conditions of farm workers and women for most of her life. Living in California as a young school teacher, Dolores noticed how malnourished her students where. Determined to help, she knew at that point that farm workers needed to organize. In 1960, Dolores started the Agricultural Workers Association and later co-founded what would become the United Farm Workers. She played a critical role in a strike against California‚Äôs grape growers and coordinated a national lettuce boycott. In 2012, she was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation‚Äôs highest civilian honor. #WomensHistoryMonth

Lt. Gen. Stacye Harris is the highest-ranking black woman in the U.S. Air Force. Stacye was born in Los Angeles and started junior ROTC when she was in high school. She went on to earn a bachelor‚Äôs degree from the University of Southern California in industrial and systems engineering. While her father was in the Air Force, it wasn‚Äôt until college when really Stacye considered becoming a pilot because this was the first time the Air Force was allowing women in college to apply for the pilot training. She received her wings in 1984 and has held numerous positions since, before becoming the first black woman to achieve the rank of lieutenant general. #WomensHistoryMonth

In 1960, Wilma Rudolph became the first American woman to win three gold medals in track and field during a single Olympic Games. Wilma was born prematurely in Tennessee and at age four she contracted the polio virus. Doctors told her she‚Äôd never walk again. She had to wear a brace on her leg until she was nine, but by age 12, Wilma had proved her doctor wrong. A few years later, she would become an Olympic champion. #WomensHistoryMonth

Women‚Äôs tennis player Billie Jean King, once ranked #1 in the world and winner of 39 Grand Slam titles, used her fame to push for equal treatment for women in sports. Born in Long Beach, California, Billie Jean started to play tennis at age 11 on California‚Äôs public tennis courts. Six years later, she and her tennis partner became the youngest women‚Äôs doubles champions at Wimbledon. A prominent advocate for women‚Äôs equality in tennis, Billie Jean accepted an offer in 1973 to play Bobby Riggs, one of the top men‚Äôs players who claimed women‚Äôs tennis was inferior to men‚Äôs tennis. During the highly anticipated and televised match ‚ÄúBattle of the Sexes,‚Äù she trounced him in straight sets, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3. Because of her efforts to push for gender equality, the U.S. Open became the first major tournament to offer equal prize money to men and women. #WomensHistoryMonth

In 2001, @HillaryClinton became the first American first lady to ever win a Senate seat. Six years before, she uttered the words that would reverberate with women across the country: ‚ÄúHuman rights are women‚Äôs rights, and women‚Äôs rights are human rights.‚Äù #WomensHistoryMonth

For the rest of Women‚Äôs History Month, I will be featuring powerful women who made a difference in others' lives. Born in New York City, Audre Lorde self-described herself as a ‚Äúblack, lesbian, mother, warrior, poet‚Äù and that is apparent in her writings. She dedicated her life to discussing and confronting racism, sexism, and homophobia. One quote of hers that was prevalent at the Women‚Äôs March in January was this: ‚ÄúI am not free while any woman is unfree, even if her shackles are very different from my own.‚Äù As Audre said, it‚Äôs imperative we all work together to lift each other up. #WomensHistoryMonth
#TBT to the Fearless For The People Tour with my husband Doug.
It is clear Attorney General Jeff Sessions lied under oath about meeting with Russian officials. He must resign immediately.

Today marks the beginning of Women‚Äôs History Month, a time to recognize the contributions and achievements of American women throughout history. Women‚Äôs History Month actually began in California in 1987 when the Sonoma school district organized a week-long celebration of women‚Äôs contributions. Students participated in essay contests and presentations, and downtown Santa Rosa held a parade. The idea caught on across the country and ever since 1987, Congress has requested that the president issue a proclamation in observance of Women‚Äôs History Month. It‚Äôs strong women like my mother who made me the person I am today. I want to know which women inspire you most ‚Äî tell me in the comments below.

As we wrap up #BlackHistoryMonth, I want to recognize that just because it‚Äôs coming to an end doesn‚Äôt mean that we should or will stop recognizing and celebrating the contributions of the black community. Black history is American history. And learning history isn‚Äôt relegated to a month. It‚Äôs up to all of us to educate each other and become the change we want to see in our communities. As President Obama, then Senator Obama, once said, "Change will not come if we wait for some other person or if we wait for some other time. We are the ones we've been waiting for. We are the change that we seek."

Harriet Tubman, well-known abolitionist and ‚Äúconductor‚Äù of the Underground Railroad, was born into slavery in Maryland. She escaped when she was in her twenties, but returned many times to rescue members of her family and other slaves. She led hundreds to freedom and in her own words, ‚ÄúI was the conductor of the Underground Railroad for eight years, and I can say what most conductors can't say ‚Äî I never ran my train off the track and I never lost a passenger.‚Äù Harriet served as a Union Army spy during the Civil War and it was announced in early 2016 that Harriet will appear on the front of the new $20 bill. #BlackHistoryMonth

Born in New York, Patricia Bath was the first black woman to complete a residency in ophthalmology and the first black female doctor to receive a medical patent. In 1988, she patented her invention the Laserphaco Probe, which improves treatment for cataract patients. Patricia also co-founded the American Institute for the Prevention of Blindness, which is dedicated to protecting, preserving, and restoring eyesight. #BlackHistoryMonth

Today for #BlackHistoryMonth, I want to celebrate former First Lady Michelle Obama. Raised in Chicago, Michelle attended Princeton University before going to Harvard Law School. As First Lady, she launched Let‚Äôs Move!, which addressed the challenges of childhood obesity, encouraged kids to get active, and provided support to parents to make healthier choices. Together with Dr. Jill Biden, the two women started Joining Forces, which became a nationwide initiative to support our service members, veterans, and their families. Throughout her life, Michelle has pushed for equal opportunities for everyone, no matter where they started out in life.

Faye Wattleton was the first black woman and the youngest president elected to run Planned Parenthood Federation of America. Born in Missouri, she graduated from The Ohio State University with bachelor‚Äôs degree in nursing. During her fourteen years as president of Planned Parenthood, Planned Parenthood expanded to become the nation‚Äôs seventh largest nonprofit organization, with 170 affiliates operating in 49 states plus the District of Columbia. Wattleton is widely credited with making Planned Parenthood an aggressive organization on the frontlines of women‚Äôs reproductive rights. #BlackHistoryMonth
Toured the damage at the Oroville Dam yesterday. We must take action to address the billions of dollars in infrastructure repairs we face.

For #TGIT fans, learn more about @shondarhimes, the brains behind Grey‚Äôs Anatomy, Scandal, How to Get Away with Murder, and more. Shonda is the first black woman to create and executive produce a Top 10 network series ‚Äî Grey‚Äôs Anatomy. Raised outside of Chicago, Shonda had an early affinity for storytelling. After college, she attended the University of Southern California to study screenwriting. Shonda worked on movies, including Crossroads and The Princess Diaries, before moving to Grey‚Äôs Anatomy, which debuted in 2005 and is still going strong. She currently runs ShondaLand, a television production company that houses all her creations. As she said during a commencement address at Dartmouth College, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard work that creates change.‚Äù #BlackHistoryMonth

Born in Los Angeles, @IssaRae was the first black female to create and star in an HBO comedy. First airing in 2016, ‚ÄúInsecure‚Äôs‚Äù first season earned her a Golden Globe nomination, and the show is set for a second season. Issa is also known for her comedy web series ‚ÄúThe Misadventures of Awkward Black Girl,‚Äù which she started because she felt like Hollywood‚Äôs stereotypes of black women were limiting and unrelatable. #BlackHistoryMonth

Ava DuVernay, born in Long Beach, California, became the first black woman to be nominated for Best Director by the Golden Globe Awards in 2014 for her work on ‚ÄúSelma.‚Äù Ava is the founder of ARRAY, an independent film distribution company that focuses on amplifying independent films by people of color and women filmmakers around the globe. Much of her work has focused on civil rights, including her Netflix documentary entitled ‚Äú13th.‚Äù This documentary highlights how the 13th Amendment played a role in mass incarceration in the United States and discusses the intersection of race and criminal justice reform. It was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature this year. #BlackHistoryMonth
Happy birthday to my dear friend, @RepJohnLewis ‚Äî thank you for showing the world what #goodtrouble looks like.

‚ÄúTell them about dream, Martin!‚Äù Such simple words shouted by ‚ÄúThe Queen of Gospel‚Äù Mahalia Jackson to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. during the March on Washington led to what some might call the greatest improvisation of the Civil Rights Movement. It‚Äôs because of Mahalia that Dr. King proclaimed, ‚ÄúI have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.‚Äù Mahalia exemplifies a woman with a strong voice who may not be as well known by the general public but had a great impact on our nation‚Äôs history. #BlackHistoryMonth

Today is the 75th anniversary of the executive order that President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed that led to the internment of 120,000 people of Japanese ancestry. California had two internment camps, including Manzanar, where more than two-thirds of the people interned there were American citizens by birth. Many of these Japanese-Americans lost their homes, their businesses, and their possessions while they were detained because of this executive order. It is vital that we all reflect on the lessons from the past so we don‚Äôt repeat the same mistakes in the future. üì∑: Dorothea Lange

A Sacramento native, Channing Dungey became the first black president of a major broadcast TV network when she was hired to oversee ABC in February of last year. Her recent accomplishment goes to show that black women continue to break through barriers every day.

In 1997, Violet Palmer became the first female referee in the National Basketball Association. Sixteen years after breaking that barrier, Violet said, "One of the things I'm proudest of is the woman thing still exists, but it doesn't matter. [The players] know when I'm out there officiating, I'm on it. I can do the work.‚Äù #BlackHistoryMonth

Yesterday, I delivered my first official speech as senator from the great State of California to address how immigrants have been targeted by the Trump Administration. From the President‚Äôs creation of a 15,000-member deportation force to his attempts to slam the gates of freedom with a heartless Muslim ban, this administration is striking a chilling fear in the hearts of millions of hardworking people. These actions run counter to our nation‚Äôs ideals and threaten our public safety and security. We can‚Äôt let that happen.

On December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks refused to give up her Montgomery bus seat to a white passenger and was promptly arrested. This act of nonviolent civil disobedience became a rallying point that sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott. While oftentimes portrayed as a woman with limited civil rights activism, at the time of her arrest, Rosa was active in her local NAACP and served as secretary. Rosa remained involved throughout the rest of her life. She served on the Board of Advocates of Planned Parenthood and co-founded the Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute for Self Development, where kids from all backgrounds can get involved in their communities. In 1996, President Clinton presented her the Medal of Freedom, the highest award given to civilians. #BlackHistoryMonth

Carol Moseley Braun went to law school and worked as a prosecutor before eventually winning a seat in the Senate. In 1992, Carol became the first black woman Senator and represented Illinois. ‚ÄúI cannot escape the fact that I come to the Senate as a symbol of hope and change,‚Äù she said shortly after being sworn in.

@LaverneCox, best known for playing Sophia Burset on Netflix‚Äôs Orange Is the New Black, was the first transgender woman of color to have a leading role on a mainstream scripted television show. Laverne was also the first transgender person to be nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award and in 2014, became the first transgender American featured on the cover of Time magazine. #BlackHistoryMonth
Wishing you and your loved ones a wonderful Valentine‚Äôs Day!

Maya Angelou was a writer and civil rights activist known best for her memoir, ‚ÄúI Know Why the Caged Bird Sings‚Äù and her beautiful poetry. She encountered many hardships throughout her life, including becoming mute for almost five years. She overcame those struggles and went on to become one of the most celebrated writers of her time. #BlackHistoryMonth

Starting early in her career as an assistant dean of graduate studies at the University of Southern California, Ruth Simmons went on to become the president of Smith College, where she started the first engineering program at a U.S. women‚Äôs college. In 2001, Ruth was sworn in as the 18th president of Brown University and the first black president of an Ivy League institution. #BlackHistoryMonth

By the fourth grade, Shawna Rochelle Kimbrell knew she wanted to be a fighter pilot. In 1999, she earned her pilot wings and just two short years later she became the first black woman combat pilot for the Operation Northern and Southern Watch in Turkey and Saudi Arabia. Here‚Äôs what she had to say about success: "Expect road blocks, expect that there are going to be people out there who don't want you to succeed, expect people are going to tell you no. But the desire that comes from within ‚Äî if it's something that you really want ‚Äî will carry you through." #BlackHistoryMonth

Ruby Bridges was just six when she became the first black child to attend an all-white public elementary school in Louisiana in 1960. She had to be escorted by federal marshals to school because protesters were throwing objects at her. She spent the day with only her teacher, Mrs. Henry, because many white parents removed their children from school, saying they didn‚Äôt want to have their children taught near a black girl. In 2011, Ruby met with President Obama in the White House, where he said, "I think it's fair to say that if it hadn't been for you guys, I might not be here." #BlackHistoryMonth
In 1980, Ursula Burns joined Xerox as a summer intern, worked her way up, and was named CEO in 2009. She became the first black woman CEO to head a Fortune 500 company. #BlackHistoryMonth

Today I‚Äôm introducing my first bill, the Access to Legal Counsel Act. This bill would guarantee access to lawyers for refugees and other travelers who are being held or detained while attempting to enter the U.S. at ports of entry. After Trump‚Äôs executive order, I received numerous reports of refugees, green-card holders, and U.S. citizens who were being held without access to volunteer lawyers. This is unjust and must be rectified. The Access to Legal Counsel Act is one step to ensure what happened at ports of entry after the executive order never happens again.

@Mistyonpointe, raised in San Pedro, California, began her ballet studies at age thirteen. In 2000, she joined the American Ballet Theatre and, fifteen years later, she was promoted to principal dancer ‚Äî making her the first black woman to ever hold that position. She has performed numerous roles, and made history as the first black woman to perform the lead of ‚ÄúOdette/Odile‚Äù in Swan Lake. #BlackHistoryMonth
Never stop persisting. #ShePersisted
#ShePersisted and became the first U.S. Olympic athlete to compete while wearing a hijab.
#ShePersisted because the voices of wise Latina women are necessary in the pursuit of justice and equality.
Wendy Davis stood for 11 hours to filibuster a restrictive abortion bill. #ShePersisted
Despite the naysayers, Shirley Chisholm became the first black major-party candidate to run for President of the United States. #ShePersisted
#ShePersisted because #BlackLivesMatter.

Thirty-one years after America first launched a man into space, Dr. Mae Jemison became the first black woman to go into space. This Black History Month, let us remember those who have broken barriers in science, sometimes going where no black woman has gone before.

This past weekend I was a part of @IWillHarness, a movement that helps you use your energy to power change in your communities and around the world. #IWillHarness

In case you haven‚Äôt heard it today: Your culture is important and your story matters.

Never forget that you have a powerful voice that is capable of inspiring great change. Call your member of Congress. Volunteer at an organization close to your heart. With your action, we can create change in our communities and throughout the world.

We can‚Äôt repeat history. President Trump‚Äôs extreme vetting executive order endangers national security and is a recruiting tool for terrorists. As a nation of immigrants, this #MuslimBan runs counter to what truly makes America great: our diversity and our compassion.

When encountering law enforcement at the airport, know your rights. (1) You have the right to an attorney if you‚Äôre a U.S. citizen or being asked questions related to anything other than your immigration status. Don‚Äôt sign anything except for the ordinary customs forms. (2) Customs officers have the right to stop and search any person or belongings, but they cannot select you for a search based on your race, gender, religious, or ethnic background. (3) You have the right to wear religious head coverings, even if asked to remove it. If you believe you are being mistreated, document the events.

Today in 1870, the 15th Amendment was ratified, granting black men the right to vote. This was just the beginning in the fight for voting rights. Even after the 15th Amendment was passed, the Ku Klux Klan and other racist groups intimidated black men who tried to vote, often times by burning their homes and churches, and even lynching. While both black men and women can vote today thanks to the 19th Amendment, the fight for voting rights has never been more important. Voting is fundamental to our democratic society, yet Republicans at all levels are actively working to deny the franchise instead of protecting the vote. We have to make it easier for everyone to vote, stop voter suppression, and zealously protect access to the ballot box for all Americans. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs critical we work on expanding early voting so everyone has ample opportunity to vote, modernize voter registration systems, and stop discriminatory voting laws. #BlackHistoryMonth

During Black History Month, I will highlight the lives and accomplishments of some of the individuals that helped define who we are as a nation. Today, I wanted to share a little bit more about Frederick Douglass. Born into slavery in 1818, he escaped when he was twenty years old and would later go on to become an abolitionist, author, and civil rights activist. He became a voice for justice: ‚ÄúIf there is no struggle, there is no progress.‚Äù
Betsy DeVos is a threat to our children‚Äôs future, which is why I will vote no on her nomination.

This weekend we asked supporters like you to tell us why you oppose President Trump‚Äôs Muslim ban. We received almost 2,000 stories. Over the next week we will share these stories and show the world that we will not stand for this. #NoBanNoWall
This poem by Emma Lazarus rests at the base of the Statue of Liberty and is a reminder of who we really are.

So proud of the hard work of the lawyers who are camped out in airports across the country. They‚Äôre on the front lines, and it is truly inspiring. Many of the architects of the civil rights era were lawyers ‚Äì Thurgood Marshall, Charles Hamilton Houston, and Constance Baker Motley ‚Äì and it is they who inspired me from a young age to want to be a lawyer and fight for justice. These lawyers will serve as an inspiration to the coming generations.

Yesterday, I spoke at the protest outside of the White House, calling on President Trump to rescind his Muslim ban. Looking out at the crowd, it reminded me of my childhood during the Civil Rights Movement. I grew up surrounded by adults marching and shouting and at the protest, I saw countless families who had brought their children. As Coretta Scott King taught us, the fight for civil rights ‚Äî the struggle for justice and equality ‚Äî must be fought and won with each generation.
Together we can fight for and win back our democracy. Let‚Äôs raise our voices.

Yesterday, on Holocaust Memorial Day, President Trump enacted an executive order that will restrict refugees from Muslim-majority countries. Make no mistake ‚Äî this is a Muslim ban. We have opened our doors to those fleeing violence and oppression for decades, by presidents on both sides of the aisle. Doing so has helped global stability and made our country stronger. We can't turn our backs on the millions of refugees who are contributing to our country and our economy. During the Holocaust, we failed to let refugees like Anne Frank into our country. We can't let history repeat itself.

When I was first elected the first woman District Attorney of San Francisco, or Attorney General of California, folks would come up to me and ask me to tell them about ‚Äúwomen‚Äôs issues.‚Äù I‚Äôd look at them and say, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm so glad you want to talk about the economy.‚Äô
#TBT to the @womensmarch last weekend. We must continue the movement we started there and get involved in our local communities.

As Governor Brown said yesterday in his address, California will not turn its back on the progress we have made on immigration, on health care, or on climate change. Your governor is with you and so am I. Just as I‚Äôve been in the past, I‚Äôm committed to ensuring that California remains a leader for the rest of the country.

Here‚Äôs a hard truth for Washington Republicans: More than 334,000 jobs will be lost in California if they repeal the Affordable Care Act. On top of those who would lose their jobs, 20 million people would have their health insurance stripped away. We need to strengthen the Affordable Care Act, not repeal it. It‚Äôs time to stop playing politics with public health.

This group just made it more difficult for women to get access to health care worldwide. You tell me what's wrong with this picture. I am offended that this administration is rejecting what America looks like, because we know from experience that a government made up of racial, gender, and economic diversity is far more capable of fighting for the vast majority of Americans.

During the Women‚Äôs March on Washington, I said, ‚ÄúWe must recommit our power and our purpose. Let's make today a beginning.‚Äù Go to womensmarch.com/100 to find out ways you can take action in your own communities.

Even if you're not sitting in the White House, even if you're not a member of the United States Congress, even if you don't run a big corporate super PAC ‚Äî you have the power. As I looked out at the incredible crowd yesterday, I knew one thing ‚Äî we the people have the power. This march is not the end, rather, this is just the beginning. We must recommit ourselves to harnessing that power and getting involved at home.
Thank you to everyone who came out to the Women‚Äôs March here in Washington, D.C. and around the country. We are stronger when we raise our voices together.

When I was growing up, my parents were activists in the Civil Rights Movement. And there‚Äôs something I remember from my childhood that really made me believe in the possibilities of our country: I saw people of all ages, all colors, all religions and all backgrounds, unified in their fight for justice. That is what I saw today at the Women‚Äôs March on Washington.
This is an extraordinary day and we should all be extremely proud because there is nothing more powerful than a group of determined sisters marching. #WomensMarch

Tomorrow I will speak at and participate in the @WomensMarch on Washington. America was founded in 1776 on the ideals that we are and should be treated as equals. In 2017, that promise still is unfulfilled. That is why I'm marching. I am marching for women of color who are marginalized across the country, especially at the ballot box. I am marching for the women who aren't paid the same as men. I am marching for the women who are under attack by politicians trying to eliminate their right to choose and limit their access to comprehensive reproductive health care. I am marching for women who can‚Äôt speak up when they‚Äôre sexually assaulted. I am marching for our immigrant and LGBTQ communities, who are still not treated equally under the law. I am marching for the women that came before us and the women that follow in our footsteps. We must come together and show the new administration that we will not be silent ‚Äî and we will not be silenced. The Republicans may have taken an election, but they did not take our power. We are not defeated and we won't give up.

Together, we have the power to defend our values and make it clear that we will not back down. We cannot throw up our hands at a time that requires all of us to roll up our sleeves. This is why we must come together right now ‚Äî not despair ‚Äî and fight for who we are and the country we want to be. 
Here‚Äôs what I envision for our future: I dream of a world where we don‚Äôt play politics with public health policy. One day, we will become a country where women have access to health care and reproductive rights. I imagine a nation where 12 million hard-working immigrants are finally able to come out of the shadows and fully participate in the full light of the American economy. To those naysayers who suggest there is no such thing as climate change, I say we can become a nation that works to save our planet from climate change and puts an end to oil companies manipulating our laws. I believe in a more perfect union without the mass incarceration of African-American men. I hope for a world where we don‚Äôt sink our college students with a lifetime of debt just so big banks and for-profit colleges can bathe in the riches. 
Our ideals are at stake right now and we will have to fight for who we are. This is a pivotal moment in the history of America. Our work is just beginning.

On President Barack Obama‚Äôs last full day in office, I wanted to thank him for everything that he‚Äôs done for our country. Eight years ago, we were a nation facing the worst economic crisis in a generation. We were losing thousands of jobs each month and the auto industry was on the verge of collapse. But President Obama turned that around and rebuilt our economy, adding 15.8 million private-sector jobs since February 2010. During his time as president, he was committed to protecting the environment and reversing climate change. His global efforts resulted in the historic Paris Climate Agreement and he protected more than 550 million acres of America‚Äôs public lands and waters. Since he entered office eight years ago, 20 million more adults have health insurance thanks to the Affordable Care Act. We can‚Äôt leave these people, some who have health insurance for the first time in years, behind in the dust. And finally, but not lastly, President Obama led the fight to protect everyone ‚Äî no matter their sex, race, religion, gender identity, sexual orientation, class, age, or ability. This list just scratches the surface of everything he‚Äôs done for our nation. We must continue his fight and ensure that the progress we made under his leadership isn‚Äôt lost.

If you were a victim of domestic violence before the Affordable Care Act was enacted, you could be denied access to health care because being a victim of domestic violence is considered a pre-existing condition. That‚Äôs not right. Call the Capitol switchboard at (202) 224-3121 and they can connect you to your Senator or House representative ‚Äî tell them to vote no on repealing the Affordable Care Act.

On Sunday, I joined my colleagues across the country in speaking up about the importance of protecting the Affordable Care Act. During this rally, I had the opportunity to speak with Steve Martin, a cancer survivor, who after being diagnosed with cancer at the age of 26 is alive today because of the Affordable Care Act. He said that, "knowing I have affordable health care is the only thing keeping me going.‚Äù I will never back down from fighting for people like Steve.

I would like to take a moment today to also celebrate Congressman John Lewis, who has shown us time and time again the value of getting into ‚Äúgood trouble.‚Äù From his groundbreaking work as a Freedom Rider and the head of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, to the March on Washington, and the March from Selma to Montgomery, he and many others have worked tirelessly to advance the cause of civil rights for all Americans. We must continue their fight for freedom and speak truth to power ‚Äî especially in the face of bullying and those who seek to silence us. The struggle may be long, and the road may be difficult, but we shall overcome.

On Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, we must remember where we stand in times of challenge and controversy defines us more than where we stand in times of comfort and convenience. Not just men, as Martin Luther King, Jr. says, but everyone of all colors, races, and creeds.

As a prosecutor, I advocated for California‚Äôs immigrant communities and immigration reform. We must protect our immigrant communities. That‚Äôs why I co-sponsored the BRIDGE Act (S. 128), which will protect DACA recipients who grew up pledging allegiance to the only flag they know ‚Äì the American flag ‚Äì from deportation.
We‚Äôve got to stop playing politics with public health. This is not a partisan issue. It‚Äôs a crucial conversation about our values as a country.
I eat ‚Äòno‚Äô for breakfast, and I‚Äôve never been a fan of the word ‚Äòcan‚Äôt‚Äô ‚Äî aimed at me or anyone else.
Congratulations Vice President Joe Biden on the Presidential Medal of Freedom ‚Äî your service to this nation is relentless and unwavering.

Throwback to the 2016 San Francisco Pride Parade. There may be bumps along the way, but I know that America will continue the progress made, and work towards full equality for the LGBTQ community. I‚Äôve been unequivocal in my support and will continue my efforts to do everything we can until all people have equal rights. #TBT

A lot has changed since President Obama was sworn in as our 44th president. Eight years ago, we were a nation facing the worst economic crisis in a generation ‚Äî now, the economy has recovered and unemployment is at 4.7%. Eight years ago, more than 44 million Americans were uninsured, now 20 million adults who didn‚Äôt have health insurance are now covered. Eight years ago, the LGBTQ community didn‚Äôt have the right to marry or openly serve in the military, now they do ‚Äî just like everyone else. Thank you, President Obama, for everything you‚Äôve done. We‚Äôve come a long way but there‚Äôs still progress to be made.
We see you and we‚Äôre here for you. You are worthy.
Up to 129 million people across the country are now protected from coverage denials and higher charges because of pre-existing health conditions ‚Äî routine occurrences before Obamacare was enacted.
Like First Lady Michelle Obama said yesterday, our nation‚Äôs youth are our nation‚Äôs future. We must do everything in our power to ensure their success.
As AG, my team & I defended consumers from predatory industries like Big Oil, Wall Street, and for-profit colleges. I won‚Äôt back down in the Senate.

More than 20 million more adults have insurance thanks to the Affordable Care Act. Some of these people who didn‚Äôt have health insurance before, like Katherine‚Äôs daughter, now have access to critical preventive services like yearly checkups at no out-of-pocket costs. I intend to fight for all those who deserve access to affordable and quality health care.

January is Human Trafficking Awareness Month. For years, I have helped lead California in the fight against human trafficking, including working with California lawmakers to pass legislation that improved law enforcement‚Äôs ability to prosecute human traffickers and ensure victims have access to restitution. We have a moral obligation to combat and end this exploitation of millions of men, women, and children for their bodies and their forced labor. It is our duty to be a voice for the voiceless and keep fighting for human rights for all people.

Last week, I asked you to submit your stories about Obamacare and what it means to you. More than 200 people across California submitted stories ‚Äî some were heartbreaking and others were hopeful. These stories reaffirmed my commitment to prioritizing access to comprehensive, affordable health care and leading the resistance against any short-sighted legislation intended to end our social contract for future generations. Over the next month, we‚Äôll be sharing these stories.

Today I was sworn-in as Senator. I‚Äôm humbled and honored to serve you and the people of California in the U.S. Senate. Let‚Äôs all roll up our sleeves, get to work, and fight for the future of our country.

As I have said before, the gains made by our opposition in this election are not permanent and with steady resolve and commitment to remain fearless regardless of the political cost, I believe we can create a diverse, inclusive society, just like the kind we have always strived to create in California.
Wishing you and your family a happy and healthy new year!

We must all remain vocal about the urgent need for criminal justice reform in this country ‚Äî not only for us, but for our children and our children‚Äôs children.

Today Kids for Kamala launches! The more kids become involved in campaigns, the more they can remind people who are running for office that they matter. Even if they can‚Äôt vote, even if they can‚Äôt write a check, they matter.
Ena Sarker is on #TeamKamala! I‚Äôm so happy to have her enthusiastic support.

Instead of a criminal justice system that responds to all crimes identically, we need to take a ‚Äúsmart on crime‚Äù approach ‚Äì one that focuses on the most serious and violent offenses and avoids treating all offenders the same way. Thank you, L. from Riverside, for sharing your story.
Thank you, #MarkLeno, for 14 years of service in our state legislature! Your passion and collaborative spirit will be missed.
A few weeks ago I asked Californians to share their personal stories about why they support criminal justice reform. Over the next few days, we‚Äôll be sharing some of the stories that stood out.

The young people participating in our criminal justice reform discussion tell me that we must work on building relationships between communities and law enforcement, and that all of us are accountable when it comes to making our criminal justice system more fair and effective. I agree wholeheartedly!
Timothy Walker isn't only an #SFSU student. He's also on the racial and identity profiling advisory board I recently swore in, and today he's part of our discussion on criminal justice reform.

Speaking with community leaders at @cocosouthla about making our criminal justice system fairer & more effective. Our discussion is focused on what I call the "three Ts" - truth, transparency, and trust.

For far too long, our country‚Äôs criminal justice system has prioritized being ‚Äútough on crime‚Äù and offered a reactive approach to crime without addressing its root causes. It‚Äôs time for a change. We must reform our system to be ‚Äúsmart on crime‚Äù by focusing on crime prevention, recidivism reduction, and innovative, data-driven methods. Together, we can make our system fair and effective ‚Äì and create safer communities.

Racial profiling, bias, and the lack of trust between law enforcement and communities of color are national problems that require national solutions. This is why I‚Äôm unveiling key priorities for reform of the criminal justice system. Read more here ‚Üí KamalaHarris.org/Learn-More

When our nation‚Äôs criminal justice system prioritizes being ‚Äútough on crime,‚Äù and responds to all crimes as equal, Americans lose. Tomorrow I will discuss how we can reform our criminal justice system and restore trust and accountability.

I‚Äôm so grateful to have the the long-term support of so many, like my friend Amelia Ashley-Ward. She has been on #TeamKamala since 2003. When I first ran for DA of San Francisco, we rented a trolley and rode up and down the streets telling San Franciscans how I would fight for justice for them. The trolley is gone, but Amelia is still helping me talk to Californians about what matters most to them!

Today marks the anniversary of the March on Washington and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.‚Äôs I Have a Dream speech. Dr.King inspired people to fight for and demand a more just nation in a time of when millions of Americans were denied basic human and civil rights. We must recommit ourselves to Dr. King's vision ‚Äî his unyielding demand for justice and an end to bigotry. #MarchOnWashington #MartinLutherKingJr #IHadADream

Today is African American Women's Equal Pay Day, which takes place on the day black women catch up to non-hispanic white men‚Äôs pay from 2015. It‚Äôs inconceivable that the average black woman earns only 63 cents to the average non-hispanic white man‚Äôs dollar for the same work. If Congress doesn‚Äôt act, this gender pay gap will never close. #BlackWomensEqualPay

Team, today we received the endorsement of President @barackobama. I am so grateful for his support, and humbled by his words: ‚ÄúI am proud to endorse Kamala Harris for United States Senate because I've seen her work.

Kamala is a lifelong courtroom prosecutor with only one client: the people of the State of California.

That's the approach she'll take to the United States Senate.

Kamala's experience has taught her that if you're going to give everybody a fair shot, you've got to take on the special interests that too often stand in the way of progress.

As Attorney General, she fought the big banks that took advantage of homeowners across the country - and she won.

She cracked down on transnational gangs exploiting women and children - and she won.

She took on big for-profit colleges that were swindling students and leaving them with a lifetime of debt and a worthless degree - and she won.

She took on big oil companies to defend California's beautiful coast and its landmark law to fight climate change - and she won.

Her leadership helped ensure the right of all Americans to marry the person they love.

And throughout her lifetime as a prosecutor, Kamala Harris has been a leading voice for criminal justice reform, challenging old dogma and insisting we be 'smart on crime' by ending mass incarceration.

Kamala Harris fights for us.  That's why I'm so proud to endorse her for United States Senator.  And if you send her to the Senate, she'll be a fearless fighter for the people of California - all the people of California - every single day.‚Äù
‚ÄãWe‚Äôre all in this together. Stay informed. Stay connected. Sign up at KamalaHarris.org.

If you work hard, you should be able to provide for your family. But for too many people, the ladder of opportunity is broken. In the Senate, I will fight for an America where the minimum wage is a living wage, and families have the tools they need to compete in the workforce. A two for one Senatorial Selfie: Here I am pictured with Senator Elizabeth Warren from Massachusetts, my current colleague, and Kamala Harris now running for Senate in California who I hope will be my colleague in January. Senator Warren is a powerful force in the Senate and one of our nation's most significant advocates and activists for economic justice. Senator Warren and I have partnered on many issues and measures from efforts to improve public education, to working to bring diversify to public pension management. Most recently we partnered on retirement security making sure that financial planners, advisors and their firms must act in the best interests of their clients (The Fiduciary Rule). I am proud to be partnering with Senator Warren now in our support and endorsement of Kamala Harris in her senate race. Kamala and I have been friends for years. She is an extraordinary person and leader. Even before she decided to run for the Senate, I was encouraging her to run because I knew she would difference for California and our nation. She is definitely a rising political star and will be a great US Senator. I am proud of her and inspired by her candidacy.

Martin Luther King, Jr. Day is very personal for me. As we celebrate Dr. King and remember the history of struggle that came before us, I wanted to share a personal memory with you.

I took this photo the last time I was in DC. As I looked up at the stunning Martin Luther King, Jr. National Memorial, I could almost hear the chants that echoed across Berkeley when my parents took me to rallies.

As a child of the Civil Rights Movement, I often say that my sister and I grew up surrounded by adults who were always marching and shouting about this thing called "justice."

The cry for justice was never more powerful, more inspiring, or more urgent, than when it came from Dr. King. He taught us that it is our moral obligation to pursue justice, equality, and peace for all, no matter their race, ethnicity, gender, religion, or sexual orientation.

We are fortunate that there are so many who are working to carry his legacy forward. The activists who march in the street to protest injustices in their communities. The pastors who demand economic opportunity in long-suffering neighborhoods. The teachers who ensure that where a child is born doesn‚Äôt determine the quality of that child‚Äôs education or what they can achieve in the future. Our collective commitment to demanding a justice system where the color of one‚Äôs skin does not predetermine the measure of justice received.

To honor Dr. King, his vision, and the great promise of this country, we must re-commit ourselves to his dream every day. Let‚Äôs go forward fearlessly, tirelessly, and resolved to work together until the promise of justice is secured for our children and our children‚Äôs children. #MLKDay

The highest honor we can pay Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. is to re-commit ourselves to fighting for the causes that defined his life and work. On January 25, 1965 Dr. King told the congregation at Tabernacle Baptist Church in Selma, Alabama that ‚Äúthe civil rights bill, as marvelous as it is, is only the beginning of a new day and not the end of a journey...‚Äù The civil rights challenges of that day ‚Äì among them voting rights, police and community relations, economic opportunity, and an equitable criminal justice system ‚Äì are still with us today. We must be inspired by Dr. King, and we must act with inspiration to achieve his vision for America.

Today, my office issued the 1st comprehensive report on the state of transnational criminal organizations in California. The growth of transnational criminal organizations seriously threatens California‚Äôs safety and economic well-being. State and local law enforcement officers are on the front lines of this fight every day. Our response must include sustained funding for their work and strong coordination at all levels of government.

I was joined by San Diego D.A. Bonnie Dumanis today at the U.S.-Mexico border crossing to discuss transnational organized crime. California‚Äôs proximity to Latin America fuels our economy but makes us a target for transnational crime. The San Ysidro Port of Entry is vital to California's commerce and our fight against transnational criminal organizations‚Äîbut a smart response must look past our state border. For this reason I am leading a bipartisan delegation of state attorneys general to Mexico to strengthen cross border coordination and communication.

Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Thanks to Second Baptist Church and the Political Clergy Council for co-sponsoring a vibrant multi-faith and multi-cultural service!

Today we celebrate the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and honor the progress we have made toward realizing his dream of justice and equality for all. His legacy has transcended nearly fifty years, inspiring generations of Americans to lead with his compassion and resolve to build a more just nation. In this spirit, today we also reflect on the road that still lies ahead to reach those who continue to suffer from inequality and injustice. To truly honor Dr. King, we must re-commit ourselves to his work and never forget that ‚Äòinjustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.‚Äô #MLK #MLKday

Today, I was honored to present Destiny Lopez, 13, with a Citizen Valor Award. Destiny, of Long Beach, received the award for her brave actions last September when she prevented the abduction of a 4-year-old girl.  Destiny and some younger kids were playing in the courtyard of their building when a man appeared and tried to take the child away.  Destiny ‚Äì who was just 4‚Äô7 at the time ‚Äì blocked his path, pushed him to the ground and took the child to safety. #hero

Today, I'm asking you to do one thing, and it has nothing to do with our campaign. When you cross paths with someone working a job that makes your day-to-day life better‚Äîand I promise you, it will happen many times today‚Äîtell them "thank you." Tell them you appreciate the work that they do. That it matters to you, and to your community. That's it. 
Say thank you to the people who build our roads and bridges. Keep our water systems working. Teach our kids and take care of the sick among us. Race into our burning buildings. Grow our food, build our cars, and pick up the garbage off our streets. 
Say thank you‚Äîbecause these are the people who make America run. Not the Wall Street bankers. Not the CEOs or hedge fund managers. Ordinary people doing extraordinary things. 
Happy Labor Day.

Nine years ago today, the Affordable Care Act was passed into law. You may remember that I had a few words to share with President Obama about how important I thought this bill was... Almost a decade later I still feel just as strongly. Not only did we increase the number of Americans with health insurance by 20 million by the time we left office, but we expanded the rights of all Americans by banning insurers from denying coverage or increasing premiums due to pre-existing conditions, requiring insurers to cover recommended preventive services including certain cancer screenings, and eliminating annual lifetime caps on insurance coverage.

This law has made a difference in the lives of countless Americans who now have the peace of mind that health care offers. 
That is a BFD.
